title: Managing Symptoms: Hot Flushes, Cold Flushes & Night Sweats
description: Hot or cold flushes or night sweats
text: Hot flushes, cold flushes and night sweats are known as vasomotor symptoms. They are common symptoms of menopause: 80% of women experiencing hot flushes during menopause. Fluctuations in oestrogen levels during perimenopause affects the brain's ability to control your body's temperature. The area of the brain responsible for temperature regulation is known as the hypothalamus. Certain things can exacerbate or trigger hot flushes, and identifying these can help you reduce the frequency and severity of hot flushes.

title: How Menopause Affects Sleep
text: Hormonal changes during menopause can disrupt your sleep patterns, as can other symptoms like night sweats, which interrupt your sleep. Habits you practice during the day will help you sleep better at night: for instance, exercising, avoiding screens before bed, and reducing your caffeine intake.

title: Managing Symptoms: Low Energy and Fatigue
text: Low energy and fatigue during menopause can be related to your hormone levels. It can also be a result of poor sleep due during this time, which can be caused by other menopause symptoms, such as night sweats. Waking up to pee during the night can also related to menopausal changes and can have an imapct on your energy levels. Fortunately, there are things you can do to increase your energy during this time.

title: Managing Symptoms: Anxiety and Mood Changes
text: Of the many symptoms of menopause, those that affect your mood and mind can be the most difficult to manage, but they are not uncommon. 23% of women say they had increased anxiety during menopause, many of them for the first time in their life. This means that no, you are not going crazy and you are not alone. Prioritising taking care of yourself will go a long way in managing these symptoms.

title: Managing Symptoms: Anxiety and Mood Changes
description: Felling anxious, low mood and mood swings

This means that no, you are not going crazy and you are not alone. Prioritising taking care of yourself will go a long way in managing these symptoms.

title: Managing Symptoms: Brain Fog and Reduced Concentration
text: Mild cognitive changes can occur during menopause, but it is important to note that these changes are temporary and often resolve after peri-menopause. This includes: forgetfulness, reduced concentration and brain fog symptoms. While these symptoms can have a big impact on our sense of self-confidence, they are a common occurrence and can be managed.

title: Managing Symptoms: Sex-related Symptoms
text: Sexual changes during menopause can be related to a variety of mental and physical symptoms, including lower sex-drive (libido), vaginal dryness, or weight gain affecting our confidence. The culprit: low oestrogen (and sometimes testosterone). Local vaginal oestrogen is very effective for vaginal dryness and painful sex.

title: Understanding the Urinary Symptoms of Menopause
description: Leaking urine when you laugh or cough
text: The urinary symptoms of menopause, such as peeing when you laugh or cough or rushing to the loo are extremely common. Half of women report them yet only 1 in 6 go to visit a doctor. Unlike some other menopause symptoms, these will not go away unless treated, so it is really important to manage them rather than suffering in silence. There is often a lot that can be done to manage these symptoms non-invasively.

title: Understanding the Urinary Symptoms of Menopause
description: Frequently peeing during day or night

title: Managing Symptoms: Joint Aches and Pains
text: Joint pain is one of those symptoms that is less often talked about in relation to the menopause, but is actually very common. These pains are most likely due to declining oestrogen and progesterone levels during peri-menopause. It is very important to take care of your joints at all ages, since they will be with you all your life.

title: Menopause Symptoms: Heart Palpitations
text: Heart palpitations is the term for when your heart feels like it is fluttering or pounding much faster than usual. During menopause heart palpitations are usually accompanied by hot flushes. Like hot flushes, we recommend paying attention to anything that might be triggering your heart palpitations.

title: Managing Symptoms: Headaches and Migraines
text: Headaches and migraines are unfortunately common in all stages of life. During the menopause, some women report an increase in headaches and migraines, which research tells us is due to fluctuating oestrogen levels. Figuring out your triggers can help you avoid migraines and headaches. Additionally, some women find therapies like acupuncture helpful for managing them.

title: Managing Symptoms: Weight Gain
text: Weight gain during menopause can be a result of the natural slowing down of your metabolism during this phase of life. Additionally, weight redistribution around the midsection is common due to hormonal changes. Paying attention to these changes will help you adapt your nutrition and exercise to help you stay healthy during menopause and beyond.

title: Managing Symptoms: Brittle Hair and Nails
description: Changes to skin, hair and nails
text: During the perimenopause, you may notice changes to your hair and nails, which may feel dryer or more brittle. These changes are normal and are a result of fluctuating hormone levels, but there are things you can do to manage them. Keeping hydrated both inside (by drinking plenty of water) and outside (by using appropriate moisturisers) will help manage these symptoms.

title: Adding Exercise to your Life during Menopause
text: No matter your age, keeping an active body is very important for your overall health. Exercise can help everything from keeping your bones healthy to keeping energy and moods high. Of course, what was a great workout at 20 may be different from a great workout at 40. We recommend alternating cardio activities like running or swimming with weight bearing exercises that work to keep your muscles and bones healthy.

title: Diet and Nutrition during Menopause
text: Paying attention to what you eat can be a powerful way to manage your menopause and its symptoms. Research tells us that our diet can affect everything from our gut health to our mood, so it is no surprise that how you eat will affect your symptoms. We advise keeping an eye on your nutrient consumption, especially making sure you are getting enough calcium, as recommended daily intake goes up when you reach 40. Many women also find phytoestrogens worth investigating, as they are found in foods and can have an oestrogen-like effect in the body when consumed regularly and in the correct quantities.

title: How Smoking Affects Menopause Symptoms
text: During peri-menopausal years, smoking can trigger certain symptoms. For instance, reports of hot flushes being triggered by smoking are quite common.  There are other aspects of your health and wellbeing that will thank you for quitting. Stopping smoking will improve the appearance of your skin and it will be less dry after you quit. Non-smokers and ex-smokers also report feeling less stressed than smokers. We know quitting is difficult, so we have some tips on how to get help below.

title: How does Menopause affect Sleep?
text: Sleeping better is a common health goal, and while it is true that adults sleep less as they get older, prioritising sleep is very important no matter your age. There are things you can do during the day to help you sleep better at night, such as avoiding caffeine and screens before bed time.

title: Emotional Fitness During Menopause
text: We like to talk about mental health in terms of emotional fitness: even if there is nothing wrong, it is important to take care of your mind so you can stay emotionally fit. This is especially important during menopause, as not just hormones affect how you feel, but there are usually other life changes happening, too. Developing healthy habits and taking time for yourself can help you stay emotionally fit.

title: Managing Weight Gain during Menopause
text: Weight loss is one of the most common health goals of women during menopause. The natural slowing down of the metabolism that comes with ageing can cause weight gain. This means that during this phase you will likely need to recalibrate what and how much you eat if losing weight is one of your goals.

title: Drinking Alcohol and its Efects on Menopause
text: Many women find that reducing their intake of alcohol during menopause helps alleviate their symptoms. We recommend being mindful of when you drink and how much, so that you can make the best decisions for you each time.
